revision.text:
'''Press support''' is a government [[subsidy]] available for [[newspaper]]s in some countries. The support can either be direct, in terms of money to the newspaper, or indirect, such as lowered or eliminated [[sales tax]]. The justification for press support is typically to maintain some level of diversity in the media market. == Press support by country == === Norway === Press support is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[subsidy|state subsidy]] available for [[newspaper]]s.{{Citation needed|date=September 2013}} The subsidy is twofold; the first part is a direct subsidy of the second- largest, by circulation, newspapers in each city. The other subsidy is that newspaper are subject to no [[sales tax]] (as are [[book]]s). ====Direct support==== The direct subsidy is managed by the [[Norwegian Media Authority]], and was [[Norwegian krone|NOK]] 303 million in 2006, paid to 138 newspapers. It was introduced in 1965, because of the fear of a massive newspaper death like [[Sweden]] and [[Denmark]] had seen, mainly the second largest newspapers in each city. Also, at the time, most newspapers were not [[political neutrality|political neutral]], with many papers being controlled by either [[conservativism|conservative forces]], the [[Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions|labour movement]] or [[List of political parties in Norway|political parties]]. Support is given to all newspapers that are do not have the largest circulation in the city of publishing. There are limitations on the newspapers who can receive support, including that the support will cease if they pay a [[dividend]] to their owners. Other support is given to [[media studies|media research]], follow-up studies, [[sami people|sami newspapers]], immigrant publications and distribution support for [[Finnmark]]. The press support has been partially successful, with a number of second-largest newspapers surviving, like ''[[Bergensavisen]]'' (Bergen), ''[[Rogalands Avis]]'' (Stavanger) and ''[[Dagsavisen]]'' (Oslo). Other secondary newspapers have been closed, like ''[[Trondheims-Pressen]]''. The largest receivers are often national newspapers, targeting special (often political) sectors, like ''[[Klassekampen]]'' (Socialist), ''[[Nationen]]'' (Agrarian) and ''[[Vårt Land (Norwegian newspaper)|Vårt Land]]'' (Christian). Most of the large, [[business newspaper|business]] and [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]] newspapers, like [[Dagbladet]] or [[Dagens Næringsliv]], do not receive support, since they pay dividend to their owners. {| class=wikitable |+Papers that receive the most support |- ! × !! Paper !! 2005 !! 2003 |- ! 1 | ''[[Dagsavisen]]'' || 40 992 576 || 39 851 052 |- ! 2 | ''[[Bergensavisen]]'' || 32 256 115 || 27 596 098 |- ! 3 | ''[[Vårt Land (Norwegian newspaper)|Vårt Land]]'' || 31 683 024 || 31 238 520 |- ! 4 | ''[[Nationen]]''|| 23 094 731 || 23 122 393 |- ! 5 | ''[[Klassekampen]]'' || 14 513 041 || 13 068 764 |- ! 6 | ''[[Rogalands Avis]]'' || 13 280 816 || 13 096 528 |} ====Indirect support==== By far the greatest level of support to newspapers arises out of their exemption from sales tax and exceeds NOK 1 billion. This exemption was instituted to foster a variety of perspectives from newspapers; to stimulate public debate and consciousness, [[democracy]], [[freedom of speech]] and to enable the media to act as society's watch-dog. {| class=wikitable |+ Indirect press support |- ! × !! Paper !! Direct
support !! Indirect
support !! Sum |- ! 1 | ''[[Verdens Gang|VG]]'' || 0 || 215 000 000 || 215 000 000 |- ! 2 | ''[[Aftenposten]]'' || 0 || 126 000 000 || 126 000 000 |- ! 3 | ''[[Dagbladet]]'' || 0 || 121 000 000 || 121 000 000 |- ! 4 | ''[[Dagens Næringsliv]]'' || 0 || 43 000 000 || 43 000 000 |- ! 5 | ''[[Dagsavisen]]'' || 29 000 000 || 14 000 000 || 43 000 000 |- ! 6 | ''[[Bergens Tidende]]'' || 0 || 42 000 000 || 42 000 000 |- ! 7 | ''[[Adresseavisen]]'' || 0 || 37 000 000 || 37 000 000 |- ! 8 | ''[[Bergensavisen]]'' || 20 000 000 || 14 000 000 || 34 000 000 |- ! 9 | ''[[Vårt Land (Norwegian newspaper)|Vårt Land]]'' || 18 000 000 || 12 000 000 || 30 000 000 |- ! 10 | ''[[Stavanger Aftenblad]]'' || 0 || 29 000 000 || 29 000 000 |- ! | Sum || 67 000 000 || 653 000 000 || 720 000 000 |} === Sweden === {{stub-section|date=January 2017}} == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{cite news|title=Presses til å gjøre kutt|url=http://www.klassekampen.no/61942/article/item/null/presses-til-a-gjore-kutt|newspaper=[[Klassekampen]]|date=2013-09-10|language=Norwegian|trans-title=Forced to make cuts}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Press Support}} [[Category:Media industry]] [[Category:Economics of the arts and literature]] [[Category:Media regulation]] [[Category:Media in Norway]]

{{More footnotes|date=April 2009}} '''Proto-Samoyedic''', or '''Proto-Samoyed''', is the [[linguistic reconstruction|reconstructed]] ancestral language of the [[Samoyedic languages]]: [[Nenets languages|Nenets]] ([[Tundra Nenets language|Tundra]] and [[Forest Nenets language|Forest]]), [[Enets language|Enets]], [[Nganasan language|Nganasan]], [[Selkup language|Selkup]], as well as extinct [[Kamassian language|Kamas]] and [[Mator language|Mator]]. Samoyedic is one of the principal branches of the [[Uralic languages|Uralic language family]], and its ancestor is [[Proto-Uralic]].
== Phonology ==
A fairly complex system of vowel phonemes is reconstructed for Proto-Samoyedic:
{| class="wikitable IPA" |- | ! colspan=2 | [[front vowel|Front]] ! colspan=2 | [[back vowel|Back]] |- | ![[unrounded vowel|Unrounded]] ![[rounded vowel|Rounded]] ![[unrounded vowel|Unrounded]] ![[rounded vowel|Rounded]] |- ![[close vowel|Close]] | align="center" |''i'' [i] | align="center" |''ü'' [y] | align="center" |''ï'' [ɯ] | align="center" |''u'' [u] |- ![[mid vowel|Mid]] | align="center" |''e'' [e] | align="center" |''ö'' [ø] | align="center" |''ë'' [ɤ] | align="center" |''o'' [o] |- ![[open vowel|Open]] | align="center" |''ä'' [æ] | align="center" | | align="center" |''a'' [ɑ] | align="center" |''å'' [ɒ] |- ![[reduced vowel|Reduced]] | colspan=2 align="center" | ''ə̈'' [ə̟] || colspan=2 align="center" | ''ə'' [ə̠] |} The system is retained relatively faithfully in [[Selkup language|Selkup]] (though expanded with [[vowel length]]). Two of the vowel contrasts are however only retained in [[Nganasan language|Nganasan]]: the distinction of front and back reduced vowels, and that of *i versus *e. For the remainder of the family, following the mergers *e > *i and *ə̈ > *ə, a further shared change is raising of *ä > *e.<ref>Helimski, Eugen: [http://helimski.com/2.222.doc, The 13th Proto-Samoyedic vowel] {{Dead link|fix-attempted=yes|date=September 2018}}. - In: Mikola-konferencia 2004. Szeged: SzTE Department of Finnougristics, 2005. 27-39.</ref> Earlier works often thus give a slightly different transcription of several vowels:<ref>{{cite journal|first=Ante|last=Aikio|title=New and Old Samoyed Etymologies (Part 2)|journal=Finnish-Ugrische Forschungen|issue=59|p=10|year=2006}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |- ! Older reconstruction !! Current reconstruction |- | *i || *i, *e |- | *e || *ä |- | *ä || *a |}
Even though the number of vowel phonemes was high, there were no long vowels or phonemic diphthongs. A peculiar feature of the reconstructed vowel system is the occurrence of vowel sequences, which consisted of any full vowel followed by the reduced vowel /ə/: for example, *''tuə'' 'feather', *''kåəså'' 'man'. These sequences were not diphthongs; the vowels belonged to separate syllables. Evidence of the vowel sequences has been preserved in only part of the Samoyedic languages, primarily in Nganasan and [[Enets language|Enets]]. Wagner-Nagy (2004)<ref>{{cite journal|first=Beáta|last=Wagner-Nagy|title=Wort- und Silbenstruktur im Protosamojedischen|journal=Finnisch-Ugrische Mitteilungen|pp=87–108|issue=26–27|year=2004}}</ref> lists the following examples: * Close + reduced: *iə, *iə̈, *üə, *üə̈, *uə, *uə̈ * Mid + reduced: *öə, *ëə, *oə, *oə̈ * Open + reduced: *äə (> *eə), *åə * Close + open: *uå * Reduced + open: *əå
Proto-Samoyedic had [[vowel harmony]] like many other Uralic languages. Harmony determined whether a front vocalic or a back vocalic [[allomorph]] of a [[suffix]] was used. However, the restrictions imposed by vowel harmony were not absolute because also disharmonic word-stems can be reconstructed. Such stems break vowel harmony by combining front and back vowels: e.g. Proto-Samoyedic *''kålä'' 'fish', *''wäsa'' 'iron'.
In contrast to the vowel system, the consonant system is rather simple with only 13 phonemes:
{| class="wikitable" |- | ![[Labial consonant|labial]] ![[Dental consonant|dental]] ![[Palatal consonant|palatal]] ![[Velar consonant|velar]] |- ![[Stop consonant|stop]] | align="center" |p | align="center" |t | align="center" | | align="center" |k |- ![[Affricate consonant|affricate]] | align="center" | | align="center" |''c'' [ts] | align="center" | | align="center" | |- ![[Sibilant consonant|sibilant]] | align="center" | | align="center" |s | align="center" | | align="center" | |- ![[Nasal consonant|nasal]] | align="center" |m | align="center" |n | align="center" |''ń'' [ɲ] | align="center" |ŋ |- ![[Lateral consonant|lateral]] | align="center" | | align="center" |l | align="center" | | align="center" | |- ![[Trill consonant|trill]] | align="center" | | align="center" |r | align="center" | | align="center" | |- ![[semivowel]] | align="center" |w | align="center" | | align="center" |j | align="center" | |- |}
The exact sound value of the affricate is not entirely clear; it may originally have been [[Retroflex consonant|retroflex]] {{IPA|[ʈ͡ʂ]}} rather than dental or alveolar {{IPA|[t͡s]}}. It has remained distinct only in Selkup, merging elsewhere with *''t''.
As in [[Proto-Uralic]], the ancestor of Proto-Samoyedic, the first syllable of words was always stressed, and hence there was no contrastive [[Stress (linguistics)|stress]]. Contrastive [[Tone (linguistics)|tones]] did not occur either.
===Phonotactics=== As in Proto-Uralic, words could begin with a maximum of one consonant: initial [[consonant cluster]]s were not allowed. Another [[phonotactic]] constraint inherited from Proto-Uralic was that the consonants *''r'' and *''ŋ'' were not allowed word-initially. Proto-Samoyedic had, however, innovated final consonant clusters in a few words. In all of them, the first consonant in the cluster was the semivowel *''j'', as in *''wajŋ'' 'breath'. Thus, the [[syllable structure]] of Proto-Samoyedic was altogether (C)V(j)(C).
Inside words, clusters of two consonants were common. Clusters of three consonants were again possible only if the first consonant of the cluster was *''j'', as in *''wajkkə'' 'neck'.
=== Later development ===
[[Palatalization (sound change)|Palatalization]] of consonants, most prominently *''k'', has occurred in all recorded Samoyedic languages. This is however a post-Proto-Samoyedic development, as the details differ in each branch due to vowel developments.<ref name = "HPUL">{{citation | last = Sammallahti | first = Pekka | author-link = Pekka Sammallahti | year = 1988 | chapter = Historical phonology of the Uralic languages, with special reference to Samoyed, Ugric, and Permic | title = The Uralic Languages: Description, History and Foreign Influences | editor = Denis Sinor | pages = 478–554 | publisher = Brill | publication-place = Leiden }}</ref> * The Nenets-Enets group palatalizes both *''k'' and *''s'' to /sʲ/. * Nganasan, Selkup and Kamassian palatalize *''k'' to a distinct /ʃ/. Nganasan also palatalizes *''s'' to /sʲ/. * Mator appears to have no palatalization of *''k''; however, *''s'' is, somewhat counterintuitively, palatalized to /k/. * Nenets-Enets and Nganasan have prominent palatalization of other consonants as well, leading to contraction of the vowel system.
Other widespread developments include [[Prosthesis (linguistics)|prothesis]] of *''ŋ'', initial lenition of *''p'', and [[fortition]] of the semivowels *''w'', *''j''. * In Nganasan, Nenets and Enets, PS vowel-initial words gain an initial /ŋ/ (which may be subsequently palatalized to /nʲ/). * PS initial *''p'' is lenited to /f/ in Enets, /h/ in Mator and Nganasan. (/f/ still appears in the oldest Nganasan records.) * PS initial *''w'' remains only in Nenets. In Selkup, it becomes /kʷ/; all other varieties shift it to /b/. * PS initial *''j'' remains in both Nenets and Enets. It becomes /tʲ/ in Selkup, and /dʲ/ in other varieties. * In Mator and Kamassian, /b/, /dʲ/ are furthermore nasalized to /m/, /nʲ/ preceding a word-internal nasal. This has been an [[Language area|areal]] change, shared also with [[Siberian Turkic]] languages such as [[Khakas language|Khakas]].<ref name=EH03>{{cite journal|first=Eugene|last=Helimski|title=Areal groupings (Sprachbünde) within and across the borders of the Uralic language family: A survey|year=2003|journal=Nyelvtudományi Közlemények|ISSN=0029-6791|url=http://www.nytud.hu/nyk/100/helimski.pdf|accessdate=2014-10-31|p=158}}</ref>
== Morphology ==
Proto-Samoyedic was a fairly typical [[agglutinative language]] with only little [[morphophonology|morphophonological]] alteration, apart from vowel harmony. In the following, ''-A'' marks an [[archiphoneme]] realized as ''-å'' in words with back-vocalic harmony, ''-ä'' in words with front-vocalic harmony.
Three [[grammatical number|numbers]] were distinguished: singular, [[dual grammatical number|dual]] and [[plural]]. Possession was indicated with [[possessive suffix]]es.
Nouns distinguished seven cases: *[[nominative case|Nominative]]: (no ending) *[[genitive case|Genitive]]: *-n *[[accusative case|Accusative]]: *-m *[[locative case|Locative]]: *-kə-nA *[[ablative case|Ablative]]: *-kə-t(ə) *[[dative case|Dative]]: *-kə- *[[Prosecutive case|Prosecutive]]: *-mə-nA
Verbs were conjugated for [[grammatical mood|mood]], [[grammatical tense|tense]], [[grammatical number|number]] and [[grammatical person|person]]. There were also separate subjective and objective [[grammatical conjugation|conjugations]].
[[Morphological derivation|Derivational]] suffixes were numerous, and could form both verbs and nominals.<ref>{{cite journal|first=Tamás|last=Janurik|year=2010|title=A közszamojéd szóanyag rekonstruálható képzői|journal=Folia Uralica Debreceniensia|volume=17|url=http://mnytud.arts.unideb.hu/finnugor/fud/fud17.pdf|accessdate=2015-03-23}}</ref>
== Development == Most Proto-Samoyedic phonemes continue the corresponding Proto-Uralic phonemes unchanged. The most prominent changes are:<ref name = "HPUL"/><ref>{{citation | last = Aikio | first = Ante | year = 2002 | title = New and Old Samoyed etymologies | journal = Finnisch-Ugrische Forschungen | issn = 0355-1253 | volume = 57 }}</ref>
* PU *''s, ś'' > PS *''t, s''. * PU *''δ'' > PS *''r''. * PU *''δ́''' as well as PU *''l'' in most positions > PS *''j''. *''l'' remains initially before PU *''ï'',<ref>{{citation | last = Michalove | first = Peter A. | year = 1999 | title = The treatment of initial *l- in Proto-Samoyed | journal = Journal de la Société Finno-Ougrienne | issn = 0355-0214 | volume = 89 }}</ref> as well as in PS intervocalic positions. * PU *''x'' > PS *''ø'', when before a consonant. * PU *''u'' > PS *''ø'' preceding a PU stem vowel *''a''. * PU *''ï'' > PS *''ë'' in PS closed syllables. * PU *''ü'' > PS *''i''. PS *''ü'' is of secondary origin. * PU stem-final *''i'' is reduced to PS *''ø̈''/''ø'' (per harmony), and if not preceded by an original consonant cluster, subsequently lost. * PU *''a, o'' generally become PS *''å'', though in many cases PS *''a'' also appears; the conditioning for this is not entirely clear. * PU stem-final *''å'' becomes PS *''ä'' after a lateral consonant (PU *''l'' or *''δ́''; this points to an intermediate stage *''ĺ'' in the development of the latter.) * PU *''o'' remains in monosyllabic roots (both primary, and those resulting from loss of final *''ø''). * PU *''k'', *''x'', *''w'', *''j'' are lost between vowels in roots of the shape *CVCi, yielding monosyllabic PS roots. * PU *''k'' and preconsonantal *''w'' are generally lost in medial consonant clusters. Examples: * PU *äjmä "needle" > PS *äjmä * PU *kala "fish" > PS *kålä * PU *muna "egg" > PS *mønå * PU *weti "water" > PS *wet * PU *nüδi "handle" > PS *nir * PU *ïpti "hair" > PS *ëptø * PU *täwði "full" > PS *tärø̈ * PU *mośki- "to wash" > PS *måsø- * PU *suksi "ski" > PS *tutø * PU *ńïxli "arrow" > PS *ńëøj * PU *käxli "tongue" > PS *käøj
== References == {{reflist|30em}} [[Juha Janhunen|Janhunen, Juha]] 1998. Samoyedic. In: Daniel Abondolo (ed.), ''The Uralic Languages'', pp. 457–479. London / New York: Routledge.
==Sources== * {{cite book |first=Juha |last=Janhunen |authorlink=Juha Janhunen |title=Samojedischer Wortschatz: Gemeinsamojedische Etymologien |year=1977 |series=Castreanumin toimitteita |volume=17 |publication-place=Helsinki |isbn=951-45-1161-1 |issn=0355-0141 }}
[[Category:Samoyedic languages]] [[Category:Proto-languages|Samoyedic]]

revision.comment: /* Major themes */ Added line and citation.
revision.text:
{{redirect|Public understanding of science|the journal|Public Understanding of Science}}
'''Public awareness of science''' ('''PAwS'''), '''public understanding of science''' ('''PUS'''), or more recently, '''Public Engagement with Science and Technology''' ('''PEST''') are terms relating to the attitudes, behaviours, opinions, and activities that comprise the relations between the general public or lay society as a whole to scientific knowledge and organisation. It is a comparatively new approach to the task of exploring the multitude of relations and linkages [[science]], [[technology]], and [[innovation]] have among the general public.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Savaget|first1=Paulo|last2=Acero|first2=Liliana|title=Plurality in understandings of innovation, sociotechnical progress and sustainable development: An analysis of OECD expert narratives|journal=Public Understanding of Science|year=2017|doi=10.1177/0963662517695056}}</ref> While earlier work in the discipline had focused on augmenting public knowledge of scientific topics, in line with the [[information deficit model]] of [[science communication]], the discrediting of the model has led to an increased emphasis on how the public [[uses and gratifications theory|chooses to use]] scientific knowledge and on the development of interfaces to mediate between [[expertise|expert]] and [[layperson|lay]] understandings of an issue.{{examples|date=October 2015}}
== Major themes == The area integrates a series of fields and themes such as: * [[Science communication]] in the [[mass media]], [[Internet]], [[radio]] and [[television]] programmes * [[Science museums]], [[aquarium|aquaria]], [[planetarium|planetaria]], [[zoo|zoological parks]], [[botanical garden]]s, etc. * Public controversies over science and technology * Fixed and mobile science exhibits * [[Science festival]]s * [[Science fair]]s in schools and social groups * [[Science education]] for adults * Science and [[social movement]]s * Media and science ([[Mediatization (media)|medialisation]] of science) * [[Consumer education]] * [[Citizen science]] * Public tours of [[research and development]] (R&D) parks, manufacturing companies, etc. * [[Science in popular culture]] * Science in text books and classrooms * Science and art
How to raise public awareness and public understanding of science and technology, and how the public feels and knows about science in general, and specific subjects, such as [[genetic engineering]], [[bioethics]], etc., are important lines of research in this area. Professor of communication, Matthew Nisbet, points up the challenge, for example, in terms of the paradox of the success of science and engineering creating the conditions that have led to the trust or distrust of experts among certain populations and that the correlation appears to be more socioeconomic than religious or ideological.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Nisbet |first1=Matthew |title=Divided Expectations: Why We Need a New Dialogue about Science, Inequality, and Society |journal=[[Skeptical Inquirer]] |date=2018 |volume=42 |issue=1 |pages=18-19 |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180619185052/https://www.csicop.org/si/show/divided_expectations |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref>
==The Bodmer report== The publication of the [[Royal Society|Royal Society's]]' report ''The Public Understanding of Science<ref name=RS-Bodmer-report>{{cite web|last1=The Royal Society|title=The Public Understanding of Science|url=https://royalsociety.org/topics-policy/publications/1985/public-understanding-science/|publisher=The Royal Society|accessdate=11 October 2015}}</ref>'' (or ''Bodmer Report'') in 1985 is widely held to be the birth of the Public Understanding of Science movement in Britain.<ref>http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/doc_WTD004707.html{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The report led to the foundation of the [[Committee on the Public Understanding of Science]] and a cultural change in the attitude of scientists to outreach activities.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld199900/ldselect/ldsctech/38/3805.htm#n26|title=House of Lords - Science and Technology - Third Report|work=parliament.uk}}</ref>
== The contextualist model == In the 1990s, a new perspective emerged in the field with the classic study of [[Cumbria]]n Sheep Farmers' interaction with the Nuclear scientists in [[England]], where [[Brian Wynne]] demonstrated how the experts were ignorant or disinterested in taking into account the lay knowledge of the sheep farmers while conducting field experiments on the impact of the [[Chernobyl]] Nuclear fall out on the sheep in the region.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Wynne|first=Brian|date=1996|chapter=Misunderstood Misunderstandings: Social Identities and the Public Uptake of Science|url=|editors=Alan Irwin and Brian Wynne |title=Misunderstanding Science? The Public Reconstruction of Science and Technology |location=Cambridge |publisher=Cambridge University Press |pages=19–46|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Because of this shortcoming from the side of the scientists, local farmers lost their trust in them. The experts were unaware of the local environmental conditions and the behaviour of sheep and this has eventually led to the failure of their experimental models. Following this study, scholars have studies similar micro-sociological contexts of expert-lay interaction and proposed that the context of knowledge communication is important to understand public engagement with science. Instead of large scale public opinion surveys, researchers proposed studies informed by [[Sociology of scientific knowledge|Sociology of Scientific Knowledge (SSK)]]. The contextualist model focuses on the social impediments in the bidirectional flow of scientific knowledge between experts and laypersons/communities.
== The deliberative turn == The scholarly debate on public engagement with science developed further into analyzing the deliberations on science through various institutional forms, with the help of the theory of deliberative democracy. Public deliberation of and participation in science practiced through public spheres became a major emphasis. Scholars like [[Sheila Jasanoff]] argues for wider public deliberation on science in democratic societies which is a basic condition for decision making regarding science and technology.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jasanoff|first=Sheila|date=2003|title=Breaking the Waves in Science Studies: Comment on H.M. Collins and Robert Evans, 'The Third Wave of Science Studies'|url=|journal=Social Studies of Science |volume=33 |issue=3 |pages=389–400|doi=10.1177/03063127030333004|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> There are also attempts to develop more inclusive participatory models of technological governance in the form of consensus conferences, citizen juries, extended peer reviews, and deliberative mapping.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lövbrand, Eva, Roger Pielke, Jr. and Silke Beck|first=|date=2011|title=A Democracy Paradox in Studies of Science and Technology|url=|journal=Science, Technology and Human Values |volume=36 |issue=4 |pages=474–496|doi=10.1177/0162243910366154|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Measuring public understanding of science == Social scientists use various metrics to measure public understanding of science, including:
=== 1. Factual knowledge === ==== Examples of measurement: ==== * Recognition: Answering a specific question by selecting the correct answer out a list<ref name="Eveland">{{cite journal|last1=Eveland|first1=William|title=How Web Site Organization Influences Free Recall, Factual Knowledge, and Knowledge Structure Density|journal=Human Communications Research|volume=30|issue=2|pages=208–233|doi=10.1111/j.1468-2958.2004.tb00731.x}}</ref> *[[Recall (memory)#Types|Cued Recall]]: Answering a specific question without a list of choices <ref name="Eveland" /> *[[Recall (memory)#Types|Free Recall]]: After exposure to information, the study participant produces a list of as much of the information as they can remember <ref name="Eveland" /> ==== Key assumptions: ==== * The more individual pieces of information a person is able to retrieve, the more that person is considered to have learned <ref name="Eveland" />
=== 2. Self-reported knowledge, perceived knowledge, or perceived familiarity === ==== Examples of measurement: ==== * Scaled survey responses to questions such as "How well informed you would say you are about this topic?"<ref name ="Ladwig">{{cite journal|last1=Ladwig|first1=Peter|title=Perceived familiarity or factual knowledge? Comparing operationalizations of scientific understanding|journal=Science and Public Policy|volume=39|pages=761–774|doi=10.1093/scipol/scs048}}</ref> ==== Key assumptions: ==== * Emphasizes the value of knowledge of one’s knowledge <ref name="Ladwig" />
=== 3. Structural knowledge: === The nature of connections among different pieces of information in memory <ref name="Eveland" /> ==== Examples of measurement: ==== * Asking study participants to assess relationships among concepts. For example, participants free recall concepts onto the first row and column of a matrix, then indicate whether the concepts are related to each other by placing an “X” in the cell if they are not. Participants then rank the remaining open cells by their relatedness from 1 (only very weakly) to 7 (very strongly related) <ref name="Eveland" /> * Study participants answer questions designed to measure elaboration involved in a task, such as “I tried to relate the ideas I read about to my own past experiences” <ref name="Eveland" /> ==== Key Assumptions: ==== * The use of [[Elaborative interrogation|elaboration]] increases the likelihood of remembering information <ref name="Eveland" />
=== Mixed use of the three measures === * While some studies purport that factual and perceived knowledge can be viewed as the same construct, a 2012 study investigating public knowledge of nanotechnology supports separating their use in communications research, as they “do not reflect the same underlying knowledge structures." <ref name="Ladwig" /> Correlations between them were found to be low, and they were not predicted by the same factors. For example different types of science media use (television versus online) predicted different constructs <ref name="Ladwig" /> * Factual knowledge has been shown to be empirically distinct from structural knowledge <ref name="Eveland" />
== Project examples == Government and private-led campaigns and events, such as [[Dana Foundation]]'s "[[Brain Awareness Week]]," are becoming a strong focus of programmes which try to promote public awareness of science.
The UK PAWS Foundation dramatically went as far as establishing a Drama Fund with the BBC in 1994. The purpose was to encourage and support the creation of new drama for television, drawing on the world of science and technology.<ref>{{cite journal|title=PAWS off science?|journal=Physics Education|date=January 1998|volume=33|issue=1|doi=10.1088/0031-9120/33/1/011}}</ref>
The Vega Science Trust<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vega.org.uk|title=The Vega Science Trust - Science Video - Homepage|work=vega.org.uk}}</ref> was set up in 1994 to promote science through the media of television and the internet with the aim of giving scientists a platform from which to communicate to the general public.
The [[Simonyi Professorship for the Public Understanding of Science]] chair at [[The University of Oxford]] was established in 1995 for the [[Ethology|ethologist]] [[Richard Dawkins]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.simonyi.ox.ac.uk/previous-holders-simonyi-professorship/professor-richard-dawkins|title=Professor Richard Dawkins - The Simonyi Professorship|work=ox.ac.uk|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514025233/http://www.simonyi.ox.ac.uk/previous-holders-simonyi-professorship/professor-richard-dawkins|archivedate=2011-05-14|df=}}</ref> by an endowment from [[Charles Simonyi]]. Mathematician [[Marcus du Sautoy]] has held the chair since Dawkins' retirement in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.simonyi.ox.ac.uk/professor-marcus-du-sautoy|title=Professor Marcus du Sautoy - The Simonyi Professorship|work=ox.ac.uk|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100531181656/http://www.simonyi.ox.ac.uk/professor-marcus-du-sautoy|archivedate=2010-05-31|df=}}</ref> Similar professorships have since been created at other British universities. Professorships in the field have been held by well-known academics including [[Richard Fortey]] and [[Kathy Sykes]] at the [[University of Bristol]], [[Brian Cox (physicist)|Brian Cox]] at [[Manchester University]], [[Tanya Byron]] at [[Edge Hill University]], [[Jim Al-Khalili]] at the [[University of Surrey]] and [[Alice Roberts]] at the [[University of Birmingham]].

[[File:Shangani Patrol, Allan Stewart.jpg|thumb|''There Were No Survivors'', a painting depicting the last stand of the [[Shangani Patrol]]. Both the painting and the story of the patrol could be considered Rhodesiana.<ref>{{cite book |title=A history of Southern Rhodesia; early days to 1934 |last=Gann |first=Lewis H. |year=1965 |edition=First |location=London |publisher=[[Chatto & Windus]] |isbn=978-0-85664-771-0 |page=118}}; {{cite book |title=Pantheons: transformations of a monumental idea |editor1-first=Richard |editor1-last=Wrigley |editor2-first=Matthew |editor2-last=Craske |date=July 2004 |publisher=Ashgate Publishing Company |location=Aldershot |isbn=978-0-7546-0808-0 |pages=202–204}}</ref>]] '''Rhodesiana''' is any [[cultural artifacts|artifact]], or collection of artifacts, which is related to the history, geography, folklore and cultural heritage of [[Rhodesia]], the name used before 1980 to refer to modern Zimbabwe (and, [[Rhodesia (name)|before 1964]], contemporary Zambia as well). Many objects, both physical and immaterial, can be defined as "Rhodesiana"; a painting of a Rhodesian landscape, for example, could be considered as such, as might a song by a Rhodesian artist, or a tale or personality from the country's history.<ref name=rw>{{cite web |title=Poems, Texts and other interesting Rhodesiana |url=http://www.rhodesia.com/docs/resource.html |publisher=[[Rhodesians Worldwide]] |location=Mesa, Arizona |accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref> The things involved need not be old, but need to possess relevant associations with Rhodesia; for Rhodesian people and their descendants, a piece of Rhodesiana will commonly arouse feelings of patriotism and nostalgia.<ref name=rw/>
==''Rhodesiana'' journal== [[File:Burnham africaweapons.jpg|thumb|Rhodesiana exhibited at [[Bulawayo]] Museum, 1912. Weapons and bandoliers used by [[Frederick Russell Burnham]] during the [[Second Matabele War]] mingle with ''[[assegai]]s'' and a tribal shield.]] The Rhodesia Africana Society used the term as the title of its historical and cultural journal ''Rhodesiana'', which was first published in 1956.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Foreword |journal=Rhodesiana |number=1 |year=1958 |publisher=The Rhodesia Africana Society |location=Salisbury |page=vii}}</ref> It renamed itself The Rhodesiana Society in 1958,<ref>{{cite journal |title=Publication No. 3 of The Rhodesiana Society |journal=Rhodesiana |number=3 |year=1958 |publisher=The Rhodesiana Society |location=Salisbury |pages=i–ii}}</ref> and published 40 issues of the ''Rhodesiana'' journal before ceasing its publication in 1979.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Final Issue |journal=Rhodesiana |number=40 |year=1979 |publisher=The Rhodesiana Society |location=Salisbury |page=1}}</ref> After Rhodesia became Zimbabwe a year later, the society renamed itself the Historical Society of Zimbabwe, and began publishing ''Heritage'' (later ''Heritage of Zimbabwe''), a similar journal to ''Rhodesiana'', in 1981.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Published by the Historical Society of Zimbabwe |journal=Heritage |number=1 |year=1981 |publisher=Historical Society of Zimbabwe |location=Salisbury |page=1}}</ref>
==Rhodesiana market== The term "Rhodesiana" may be used to describe the theme of a museum or collection, or to summarise the character of goods for sale.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Rhodesiana for sale |journal=Contact! Contact! |url=http://www.rhodesianservices.org/user/image/publication04-2011.pdf |date=April 2011 |publisher=Rhodesian Services Association Incorporated |location=Tauranga, New Zealand |page=16 |format=pdf}}</ref> Indeed, a London-based dealer of African memorabilia, David Saffery, reported in 2002 that Rhodesiana was one of his best-selling lines, with the majority of customers being expatriates, "most of whom still describe themselves as Rhodesians".<ref name=outofafrica>{{cite journal |title=Rhodesiana – it's Hot Stuff! |last=Saffery |first=David |work=Out of Africa International |issue=3 |volume=3 |date=November–December 2002 |url=http://archive.hmvh.net/ooai/ooai18.pdf |pages=13–14 |format=pdf}}</ref> Particularly popular items included [[Flags of Rhodesia|civil and military flags]], banknotes of the [[Rhodesian pound]] and [[Rhodesian dollar|dollar]], stamps, documents and medals. Since 1980, Zimbabwean embassies and high commissions around the world have at various times raised money by selling off obsolete [[Rhodesian passport]]s, documents, tableware, furniture and various curios. The Zimbabwean government itself entered the Rhodesiana market in 2002, when it sold off 9,000 unclaimed Rhodesian [[General Service Medal (Rhodesia)|General Service Medal]]s.<ref name=outofafrica/>
== See also == * [[Ethos]] * [[Culture of Zimbabwe]] * [[Americana]] – a similar concept in the [[United States]] * [[Australiana]] – a similar concept in [[Australia]] * [[Canadiana]] – a similar concept in [[Canada]] * [[Kiwiana]] – a similar concept in [[New Zealand]]
